lines.text:
[Marcellus has just been sentenced to execution; Diana leaves the podium to stand at his side]
Sire, Marcellus is my chosen husband. I wish to go with him.
Stand back! You're not on trial! There's no evidence against you!

Then if it please you, sire, I'll provide evidence. I have no wish to live another hour in an empire ruled by *you*! You dare to call yourself a Caesar. Once the Caesars of Rome were noble, but in you, noble blood has turned to poison. You corrupt Rome with your spite and malice.
Stop! Stop it!
That *you* should be Caesar, vicious, treacherous, drunk with power, an evil, insane monster posing as emperor.
STOP IT!
As for me, I have found another king. I want to go with my husband into his kingdom.
Then, by the gods, you shall! Go, both of you, into your kingdom!
Why must men doubt? Tell them they must keep faith! They must keep faith!
[walking away]
Wait, tell who? Who are you?
My name is Judas.
Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do.
Let me tell you of the burden I bear. Justus told the others I was steadfast. He didn't know. The night Jesus needed me most, I denied him... not once... but 3 times. I swore I never knew him. Now...

[stammering, pointing to himself]
I... crucified him.
I know. Demetrius told me.

[shocked]
And you can forgive me?
He forgave you from the cross. Can I do less? Now, is there anything stopping you? Can you become one of us?

[new strength in his voice]
From this day forward, I am enlisted in His service. I offer Him my fortune, my sword, and my life. And this I pledge to you on my honor as a Roman.
After forty years with Julia, my approaching death holds few terrors for me.
Then all the tales I've heard of you are true.
Every man makes enemies.
All your enemies seem to be women.
Until now you only remembered what you did to a man. The wrong, and your shame. But now - you remember the man.
You put him to death? Then why are you risking your life for him?
I owe Him more than my life.
It's good to see you, Marcellus.
It's ah - good to see you - again.
Then you do remember me?
Ah - yes, of course. Let me see now, it was the - was the...
And your promise, have you forgotten that too?
What promise?
To marry me.
Was I drunk?
That's not very flattering, Marcellus.
Oh, I - I mean, if you'd tell me when I was supposed to have said this - the circumstances...

Oh, I remember them perfectly. I'd cut my finger, and I cried. And then you took the dagger and cut your own finger to show that it didn't really hurt, and then you kissed me, and I stopped crying - and then you promised to marry me when we grew up.
Dianna! Where have your freckles gone?
I lost them.
Oh, I loved every one of them.
Then I'm sorry I lost them.
Even my wife had an opinion.
[repeated line]
Were you... out there?
When it comes, this is how it will start. Some obscure martyr in some forgotten province, then madness. Infecting the legions, rocking the empire, then the finish of Rome.

[awaking to darkness]
Is it night?
No. It's the middle of the day. This isn't like other days.
Give me water to wash my hands.
Tell me, what was your impression of Pilate?
It's not my place to...
I'm asking you. Did you find him capable?
Yes sire, he's considered a good administrator.
Stern, as befits a Roman governor?
I'm sure of that, sire.
Just?
I - I can't say.
Why not? Surely you can give me some sort of an answer? Tell me, tribune - what happened out there?
You're afraid, but you really don't know the reason why. You think it's his robe that made you ill. But it's your own conscience, your own decent shame. Even when you crucified him you felt it.
Are you still ill?
No, I'm well. Really well, for the first time in my life.
No, Marcellus, they'll kill you!
You must have faith...
Faith in what? This new God of yours? How can he help you? He couldn't help his own son. They crucified him and they'll kill you too!
Tribune Gallio, you are a Roman officer. I command you to gain control over yourself.
Perhaps you don't believe that a girl of eleven could fall in love, and stay in love all these years...
Don't cry, my love. Lucia thought I was in love, and I laughed at her, but women are wise in these matters.
They're going into a better kingdom! They're going into a better kingdom! They're going to meet their king! They're going to meet their king!

[to Marcellus]
You crucified him. You, my master. Yet you freed me. I'll never serve you again, you Roman pig. Masters of the world, you call yourselves. Thieves! Murderers! Jungle animals! A curse on you! A curse on your empire!
Make Pilate understand that if he stains his hands with his blood, he's worse than a murderer.

[waking up from a nightmare of Jesus being nailed to the cross]
No! No! Stop it! Stop it!

[runs out on deck]
Stop it! Why don't you stop it!
Stop what, sir?
Were you out there?
Surely you don't believe he rose from the dead.
He lives more surely than we do.
He's DEAD! And no moonstruck girl can sing him to life again!
How do you know that he's dead?
The soldier told me. The soldier who saw the lance thrust into his side. The soldier who was - out there!
What's wrong?
Were you out there?
Enough for now. He's no use to us dead.
For your sake I interfered, when my wife wanted to give you to Caligula. For your sake I brought your tribune back from Palestine. For your sake, I now free you from him.
Sire, I have no wish to be free.
Have you gone mad too?
He had everything then. He could have had me too. I wanted him, but I wasn't sure that I loved him. Now I am sure.
I see it my duty to forbid you to see him again. As a child you were wise, but now you reason like a woman - foolishly.
